column1: Carlsbad is a coastal city in the North County region of San Diego County
column2: California
column3: United States. The city is 87 miles (140 km) south of downtown Los Angeles and 35 miles (56 km) north of downtown San Diego and is part of the San Diego-Carlsbad
column4: CA Metropolitan Statistical Area. Carlsbad is a popular tourist destination. The city's estimated 2019 population was 115
column5: 382. Among the nation's top 20 wealthiest communities
column6: Carlsbad is the 5th richest city in the state of California with a median household income close to $105

column1: Carlsbad's history began with the Luiseño people (the Spanish name given to them because of their proximity to Mission San Luis Rey). Nearly every reliable fresh water creek had at least one native village
column2: including one called Palamai.  The site is located just south of today's Agua Hedionda Lagoon.The first European land exploration of Alta California
column3: the Spanish Portolà expedition of 1769
column4: met native villagers while camped on Buena Vista Creek. During the Mexican period
column6: the southern portion of Carlsbad was granted as Rancho Agua Hedionda to Juan María Marrón.

column1: In the 1880s a former sailor named John Frazier dug a well in the area. He began offering his water at the train station and soon the whistle-stop became known as Frazier's Station. A test done on a second fresh-water well discovered the water to be chemically similar to that found in some of the most renowned spas in the world
column2: and the town was named after the famed spa in the Bohemian town of Karlsbad (now Karlovy Vary
column3: Czech Republic).To take advantage of the find
column4: the Carlsbad Land and Mineral Water Company was formed by a German-born merchant from the Midwest named Gerhard Schutte together with Samuel Church Smith
column5: D. D. Wadsworth and Henry Nelson. The naming of the town followed soon after
column6: along with a major marketing campaign to attract visitors. The area experienced a period of growth
column7: with homes and businesses sprouting up in the 1880s. Agricultural development of citrus fruits
column8: avocados and olives soon changed the landscape. By the end of 1887
column9: land prices fell throughout San Diego County. However
column10: the community survived on the back of its fertile agricultural lands.

column1: The site of John Frazier's original well can still be found at Alt Karlsbad
column2: a replica of a German Hanseatic house
column3: located on Carlsbad Boulevard.

column2: Carlsbad was incorporated to avoid annexation by its neighbor
column3: Oceanside.The single-runway Palomar Airport opened in 1959 after County of San Diego officials decided to replace the Del Mar Airport.  The airport was annexed to the City of Carlsbad in 1978 and renamed McClellan-Palomar Airport in 1982 after a local civic leader

column2: Carlsbad Skatepark
column3: was built in March 1976. It was located on the grounds of Carlsbad Raceway and was designed and built by inventors Jack Graham and John O'Malley. The site of the original Carlsbad Skatepark and Carlsbad Raceway was demolished in 2005 and is now an industrial park. However
column4: two skateparks have since been developed.

column2: Legoland California was opened. It was the first Legoland theme park outside of Europe and is currently operated by Merlin Entertainments. Merlin Entertainments owns 70 percent of the shares
column3: and the remaining 30 percent is owned by the  LEGO group and Kirkbi A/S.Carlsbad is home to the nation's largest desalination plant. Construction of the Carlsbad Desalination Plant at the Encina Power Station was completed in December 2015.

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 39.1 square miles (101 km2) of which 37.7 square miles (98 km2) are land and 1.4 square miles (3.6 km2) are (3.55%) water
column3: the majority of which is contained within three lagoons and one lake.

column1: The northern area of the city is part of a tri-city area consisting of northern Carlsbad
column2: southern Oceanside and western Vista.

column1: The ocean-side cliffs fronting wide white-sand beaches and mild climate attract vacationers year-round.
Carlsbad has a semi-arid Mediterranean climate (Koppen classification BSh) and averages 263 sunny days per year. Winters are mild with periodic rain. Frost is rare along the coast
column2: but sometimes occurs in inland valleys in December and January. Summer is almost rain free
column3: but sometimes overcast and cool with fog off the Pacific. While most days have mild and pleasant temperatures
column4: hot dry Santa Ana winds bring high temperatures on a few days each year

column1: Carlsbad has Coaster and Amtrak rail service at its two stations
column2: Carlsbad Village station and Carlsbad Poinsettia station.

column1: North County Transit District provides public transportation services in Carlsbad. They operate bus service under the BREEZE brand and SPRINTER light rail service.
Interstate 5 runs through the western part of Carlsbad while California State Route 78 passes close to its northern border.
McClellan–Palomar Airport is located about 7 miles (11 km) southeast of downtown Carlsbad
column2: and allows general aviation and limited commercial service to the city.

column1: For city planning and growth management purposes
column2: Carlsbad is divided into four distinct quadrants.

column1: The northwest quadrant of Carlsbad (ZIP code 92008) includes the downtown "Village
column2: the Barrio, and Old Carlsbad." It was the first part of Carlsbad to be settled. Homes range from 1950s cottages and bungalows to elegant mansions on the hill overlooking the ocean. It is also home to Hosp Grove Park
column3: a grove of eucalyptus trees relatively untouched by development and now designated by the city for recreational use
column4: in addition to the Buena Vista and Agua Hedionda Lagoons. It is located west of El Camino Real and north of Palomar Airport Road.

column1: The Barrio area is near downtown Carlsbad bordered by Carlsbad Village Drive to the north
column2: Tamarack Avenue to the south
column3: Interstate 5 to the east and the railroad tracks to the west. It was settled by Latinos in the early 20th century. It is the site of the Centro de Aprendizaje
column4: a Spanish division of the Carlsbad City Library.

column1: This quadrant (ZIP code 92010) is located east of El Camino Real and north of Palomar Airport Road and consists mostly of single-family homes
column2: with larger lots found in the older area known as Chestnut Hills and the newer developments around Calavera Hills.

column1: The Northeast quadrant also contains the Lake Calavera Nature Preserve
column2: a 110-acre space containing a 513-foot extinct volcano known as Mount Calavera. The preserve — notable for its small lake
column3: wide dam
column4: and mountain — was officially set aside in the 1990s as the surrounding land was being developed. The preserve is bordered on three sides by suburban single-family homes
column5: and on one side by small farms and rural compounds. In 2012
column6: Sage Creek High School was developed in the southwest corner of the preserve amid some controversy. Nature experts challenged the decision to construct the school on the preserve
column7: but Carlsbad High School was reaching its capacity and there were few undeveloped areas that had sufficient space for an additional high school. Despite missing one of its original corners
column8: the preserve still offers miles of hiking trails with ocean views.

column1: The southeast quadrant (ZIP code 92009) is located east of El Camino Real and south of Palomar Airport Road and features several newer expensive master-planned communities set among hillsides
column2: golf courses
column3: Alga Norte Community Park and permanent open spaces. It includes Bressi Ranch and the La Costa neighborhoods of Rancho La Costa
column9: La Costa gave its name to the Gold Medal Golf Resort
column11: now known as the Omni La Costa Resort and Spa. Residents here are served by the Carlsbad Unified School District
column12: San Marcos Unified School District and the Encinitas Union School District.

column1: This quadrant (ZIP code 92011) extends along the Pacific Ocean to the south of the center of Carlsbad. It includes the Aviara neighborhood
column2: which is home to the Park Hyatt Aviara Resort. It is located west of El Camino Real and south of Palomar Airport Road.

column1: Carlsbad voters in 2008 voted to make Carlsbad a charter city. City government is led by an elected mayor and four council members
column2: elected at large.

column1: Carlsbad's current mayor is Matt Hall
column2: who has served since 2010. Starting with the 2018 elections
column3: Carlsbad will go from having its city council members being at large to district representation. The mayoral office will remain at large.The city has drafted ordinances protecting sensitive wildlife habitat
column4: becoming one of the first municipalities in California to do so. The city has also pledged to protect about 40 percent of the city as permanent open space.In May 2018
column5: the Carlsbad city council voted 4–1 against California sanctuary cities.

column2: Carlsbad is in the  36th Senate District
column3: represented by Republican Patricia Bates
column5: represented by Democrat Tasha Boerner Horvath.In the United States House of Representatives
column6: Carlsbad is in California's  49th congressional district

column1: Carlsbad's core industries include information technology
column2: video game development
column3: manufacturing
column11: design development and real estate. In 2013
column12: Google named Carlsbad the digital capital of California with the strongest online business community.Carlsbad is also known as the "Titanium Valley" because of its golf manufacturing industry. Callaway Golf Company
column16: and Odyssey Golf are all located in Carlsbad.
